report.report_text:
[Report de-identified (Safe-harbor compliant) by De-ID v.6.22.06.0]
**INSTITUTION EMERGENCY DEPARTMENT PATIENT NAME: **NAME[AAA, BBB M] ACCOUNT #: **ID-NUM DATE OF SERVICE: **DATE[Jul 02 06] PRIMARY CARE PHYSICIAN: A N HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: CHIEF COMPLAINT: light-headedness. HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: This patient is a **AGE[in 50s]-year-old male with a past medical history significant for coronary artery disease, status post stenting, hepatitis B, spinal meningitis in 2003 with a former epidural pump for chronic back pain, presents with light-headedness. The patient states that all day today he has felt light-headedness with a headache. He feels as if he is going to pass out. He has not hit his head. He also endorses some neck pain today. He denies any fever. There was no shortness of breath, no cough, no abdominal pain; however, he has felt nauseous all day. He has no chest pain or palpitations. No urinary symptoms. He states that these symptoms feel similar to when he was diagnosed with hepatitis one month ago.
REVIEW OF SYSTEMS: In general the patient denies any fever or chills, weakness or fatigue. HEENT: Does have a headache, no head trauma. Eyes; No blurry vision or floaters. Ears: No earache, decreased hearing. Nose no nasal discharge or pain. Throat with no throat pain or dysphagia. Respiratory: No chest pain or palpitations. Respiratory: No shortness of breath, coughing or wheeze. GI: No abdominal pain, no nausea, vomiting, diarrhea or JVD. GU: No dysuria or hematuria. Musculoskeletal: No arthralgia or myalgia. Neuro: There is presyncope. No numbness or weakness. PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Hepatitis B, chronic back pain, hypertension, coronary artery disease, status post stenting times two, meningitis in 2003, former epidural pain pump removed in **DATE[Feb 07]. MEDICATIONS INCLUDE: 1. Cardizem. 2. Celexa. 3. Imdur. 4. Prilosec. 5. Zofran. 6. Baclofen. 7. Baby aspirin. 8. Dilaudid. ALLERGIES: 1. FENTANYL. 2. MORPHINE. SOCIAL HISTORY: One-half pack of cigarettes per day, no alcohol and no illicit drug use. FAMILY HISTORY: Noncontributory. PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: Vital Signs: Temperature 37.1, pulse 71, respirations 17, blood pressure 112/74. In general, the patient is awake, alert, no apparent sign of distress. HEENT: The head is atraumatic, normocephalic. Eyes-Pupils equal and reactive to light. Extraocular movements are intact. The throat shows moist mucous membranes. Normal elevation of the soft palate. There is no erythema or exudate. Neck: The neck is supple, no meningeal signs are present. No _______ plantaris palpation. Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs, rubs, or gallops. Respiratory: Good breath sounds throughout. No crackles or wheezes. Abdomen: Positive bowel sounds. Soft. Nontender, nondistended. There is no guarding or rebound. Musculoskeletal: Pulses 2+ bilaterally. No clubbing, cyanosis, or edema. Neurologic: Cranial nerves II through XII grossly intact. Motor strength 5/5 in all four extremities. Sensation is normal bilaterally. LABS included chem 7 which is unremarkable. LFTs were obtained which showed total bilirubin 1.6, which is down from 2.6. ALT 51, AST 59, alkaline phosphatase 134, lipase 55, troponin is negative. CBC is unremarkable. Coags are within normal limits. Urinalysis was negative. Chest x-ray, 2 views, shows no active disease. EKG shows normal sinus rhythm, no acute ischemic changes. Normal intervals. ED COURSE: The patient presents feeling light-headed all day. He is in normal sinus rhythm. However, the patient does have a history of cardiac disease. Therefore, we proceeded with cardiac evaluation. The patient was also given some fluid, Reglan and Dilaudid for his nausea and abdominal pain. The patient is nontoxic appearing. I doubt meningitis. He is afebrile and nontoxic appearing. He has a benign abdomen. He states that this does feel similar to when he had hepatitis in the past, however, his LFTs are improved. Due to his cardiac disease and his presyncope, we felt it best to admit the patient to cardiac bed. This will be discussed with the patient's PCP. DISPOSITION: Admit to a telemetry bed. DIAGNOSIS(ES): PRESYNCOPE.
___________________________________ **NAME[VVV] SUYAMA
Dictator: **NAME[WWW M. XXX], M.D. CDC/drl D: **DATE[Jul 02 2007] 21:32:42 T: **DATE[Jul 02 2007] 21:37:07 R: **DATE[Jul 02 2007] 21:37:07/drl Job ID: 329574/**ID-NUM Cc:
